data.title: Famous People Born in 1868
data.meta_description: Celebrate the birthdays of 158 famous people, historical figures and celebrities born in 1868 like Nicholas II, Marie Dressler and Robert Falcon Scott.
data.text:
Snitz Edwards [Edward Neumann], Hungarian-American stage and silent film actor ("Phantom of the Opera"; "College"), born in Budapest, Austria-Hungary (d. 1937)

Arthur Gore, British tennis player (Wimbledon 1901, 08-09), born at Lydhurst, England (d. 1928)

Franz Cumont, Belgian religious historian and archaeologist (cult of Mithra), born in Aalst, Belgium (d. 1947)

Vittorio Monti, Italian violinist, mandolin player, conductor, and composer (Csárdás), born in Naples, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1922)

Mark Lidzbarski, Polish-German philologist, born in Płock, Russian Empire (d. 1928)

Frank Watson Dyson, English astronomer, proved Einstein right about light bent by gravity, born in Measham, England (d. 1939)

S. P. L. Sørensen, Danish chemist (d. 1939)

Cai Yuanpei, Chinese philosopher and educator (President of Peking University), born in Shaoxing, China (d. 1940)

Catharina Anna Maria de Savornin Lohman, Dutch author (Belief), born in Assen, Netherlands (d. 1930)

Noe Zhordania, Georgian journalist and politician (Prime Minister, 1918-21; government-in-exile leader, 1921-53), born in Lanchkhuti, Kutais Governorate, Imperial Russia (now Georgia) (d. 1953) [some sources give birthday as March 21]

Cyril Metodej Hrazdira, Czech composer and conductor, born in Rájec nad Svitavou, Moravia, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1926)

Bob McLeod, Australian cricket medium pace bowler (6 Tests, 12 wickets, BB 5/53; Victoria), born in Melbourne, Australia (d. 1907)

Jan 19 Gustav Meyrink, Austrian writer (The Golem), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1932)

Felix Hoffmann

German chemist (synthesized aspirin and heroin), born in Ludwigsburg, Germany [1]

Juventino Rosas, Mexican composer and violinist, born in Santa Cruz de Juventino Rosas, Mexico (d. 1894)

Cato Engelen-Sewing, Dutch soprano prima donna (Dutch Opera), born in Amsterdam (d. 1961)

Frederic Lamond, Scottish composer, pupil of Liszt, born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 1948)

Jan 28 Julian Aguirre, Argentine composer, born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1924)

Theodore W. Richards, American chemist (1st American to win the Nobel Prize for Chemistry for atomic weights 1914, awarded 1915), born in Germantown, Pennsylvania (d. 1915)

Dámaso Ledesma, Spanish organist, composer, musicologist, and priest, born in Ciudad Rodrigo, Spain (d. 1928)

Constance Markievicz, Irish politician, revolutionary and suffragist (1 woman elected to UK House of Commons, 1st female cabinet minister in Europe), born in London, England (d. 1927) [1]

Lodewijk Mortelmans, Belgian composer (Morgenstemming - Morning Mood), born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1952)

Syd Callaway, Australian cricket all-rounder (3 Tests, 6 wickets, BB 5/37, HS 41; NSW CA, Canterbury [NZ]), born in Sydney, Australia (d. 1923)

William Allen White, American journalist (Emporia Gazette, Pulitzer 1942), born in Emporia, Kansas (d. 1944)

Henricus Andreas Poels, Dutch Roman Catholic theologist and social foreman, born in Venray, Netherlands (d. 1948)

Wilhelm Schmidt, German anthropologist and linguist (Anthropos), born in Hörde, Germany (d. 1954)

Henri Polak, Dutch labor leader (General Diamond Workers' Union), journalist, and Social-Democrat politician (Member of Parliament), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1943)

W.E.B. Du Bois

American civil rights activist, writer (Souls of Black Folk) and co-founder of the NAACP, born in Great Barrington, Massachusetts

Anthony John Blok, Dutch lawyer (strafproces), born in Hees, Netherlands (d. 1934)

Leonard Borwick, English concert pianist, born in Walthamstow, England (d. 1925)

Alaska P. Davidson, America's first female FBI agent, born in Warren, Ohio (d. 1934)

Alain [Emile-Auguste Chartier], French philosopher and writer, born in Mortagne-au-Perche, France (d. 1951)

Prosper Poullet, Belgian politician (Prime Minister of Belgium 1925-26), born in Leuven, Belgium (d. 1937)

Grace Chisholm Young, English mathematician (d. 1944)

Maude Abbott, Canadian physician (world expert on congenital heart disease), born in St Andrews East, Quebec (d. 1940) [1]

Hamish MacCunn, Scottish composer (The Land of the Mountain and the Flood), and teacher, born in Greenock, Scotland (d. 1916)

Robert A. Millikan

American physicist (photoelectric effect; Nobel 1923), born in Morrison, Illinois

Dietrich Eckart, early supporter of Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party and member of Thule Society (d. 1923)

Bill Lockwood, English cricket fast bowler (12 Tests, 43 wickets, BB 7/71, 1 x 50; Surrey CCC), born in Nottingham, England (d. 1932)

Fuʾād I [Aḥmad Fuʾād Pasha], King of Egypt (1922-36), born in Cairo, Egypt (d. 1936)

Patty Smith Hill, American composer, teacher and songwriter ("Happy Birthday To You"), born in Anchorage, Kentucky (d. 1946)

Cuno Amiet, Swiss painter and illustrator, born in Solothurn, Switzerland (d. 1961)

Maxim Gorky

Russian playwright and author (Mother and The Lower Depths), born in Nizhny Novgorod, Russia

Mar 28 Wojciech Gawroński, Polish pianist and composer, born in Sejmany, Russian Empire (now Lithuania) (d. 1910)

Obe Postma, Frisian poet (Fan wjerklank en bisinnen / Of resonance and reflection), naturalist, and historian, born in Cornwerd, Netherlands (d. 1963)

Karl Bonhoeffer, German psychiatrist and neurologist (resisted Nazi's Aktion T4 extermination campaign), born in Neresheim, Württemberg (d. 1948)

Edmond Rostand, French poet and playwright (Cyrano de Bergerac), born in Marseille, France (d. 1918)

Eduard Jacobs, Dutch cabaret artist, born in Amsterdam (d. 1914)

Felipe G. Calderon, Filipino lawyer, politician, educator, and co-author of Malolos Constitution (of the First Philippine Republic), born in Santa Cruz de Malabon, Cavite, Philippines (d. 1908)

Flooi Du Toit, South African cricketer (one Test South Africa 1892), born in Jacobsdal, Orange Free State (d. 1909)

George Arliss

British Academy Award-winning actor (Disraeli; Devil; Green Goddess), born in London, England

Akiyama Saneyuki, Japanese officer in the Imperial Japanese Navy, born in Matsuyama, Iyo Province, Japan (d. 1918)

John Blackwood McEwen, Scottish classical composer, born in Hawick, Scotland (d. 1948)

Peter Behrens, German architect, born in Hamburg, North German Confederation (d. 1940)

Karel Rudolph Gallas, Dutch lexicographer (French Dictionary), born in Amsterdam (d. 1956)

Didericus van Epen, Dutch genealogist (Dutch Patriarch), born in Amsterdam (d. 1930)

Max Von Schillings, German composer and conductor (Der Pfeifertag), born in Düren, Germany (d. 1933)

Robert Herrick, American novelist (Common lot), born in Cambridge, Massachusetts (d. 1938)

Archduchess Marie Valerie of Austria, 4th and last child of Franz Joseph I of Austria and Elisabeth of Bavaria, born in Ofen (Buda), Austria-Hungary (d. 1924)

Apr 22 José Vianna da Motta, Portuguese composer, born in São Tomé, São Tomé and Príncipe (d. 1948)

John Bevins Moisant, American pioneer aviator, first to cross English Channel with passenger and a cat, killed in New Orleans whose present day airport was originally name for him, born in Kankakee, Illinois (d. 1910)

Harold Sidney Harmsworth, 1st Viscount Rothermere, English newspaper (Daily Mail and Daily Mirror), born in London, England (d. 1940)

Georgy Voronoy, Russian mathematician (Voronoi diagram), born in Zhuravki, Poltava Governorate, Russian Empire (d. 1908)

Apr 28 Joel Engel, Russian musicologist (Jewish Folksongs), composer "Numi Numi"), and music publisher, born in Berdyansk, Russian Empire (d. 1917)

Gaston Leroux, French writer (The Phantom of the Opera), born in Paris (d. 1927)

Władysław Reymont [Rejment], Polish novelist (Chłopi (The Peasants) - Nobel Prize for Literature, 1924), born in Kobiele Wielkie, Petrokov Governorate, Congress Poland, Russian Empire (now Poland) (d. 1925) [1]

Ed Barrow, American Baseball HOF manager (World Series 1918 Boston Red Sox) and executive (10 x World Series NY Yankees), born in Springfield, Illinois (d. 1953)

Halsey William Wilson, American publisher of reference books (Readers' Guide, Cumulative Book Index, Book Review Digest), born in Wilmington, Vermont (d. 1954)

Paolo Gallico, Italian-American concert pianist, composer (The Apocalypse), and educator, born in Trieste, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1955)

Magnus Hirschfeld

German physician and gay rights advocate, born in Kolberg, Prussia

Horace Elgin Dodge, American automobile manufacturing pioneer (co-founder of Dodge Brothers Company), born in Niles, Michigan (d. 1920)

Nicholas II

last Tsar of Russia (1894-1917), born in Saint Petersburg, Russia

John Fillmore Hayford, American Geodesist who established the theory of isostasy and founded the modern science of geodesy (precise measurements of the shape of the earth), born in Rouses Point, New York (d. 1925)

Charles E. Taylor, American first aircraft maintenance professional, born in Cerro Gordo, Illinois (d. 1956)

Claude Anet [Jean Schopfer], French writer (Fille Perdue), born in Morges, Switzerland (d. 1931)

John Hope, American educator (President of Atlanta Baptist/Morehouse College,1906-36 and Atlanta University, 1929-36), born in Augusta, Georgia (d. 1936)

(Ivar) Henning Mankell, Swedish pianist and composer, born in Härnösand, Sweden (d. 1930)

Jun 3 Aristides Agramonte y Simoni, Cuban-American Physician, Pathologist and Bacteriologist (yellow fever), born in Camagüey, Cuba (d. 1931)

James Connolly, Irish socialist (founder of the Irish Socialist Republican Party), born in Cowgate, Edinburgh, Scotland (d. 1916)

Robert Falcon Scott

British explorer and leader of the ill-fated south pole expedition, born in Plymouth, England

Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Scottish architect, designer, and illustrator, born in Townhead, Glasgow (d. 1928)

Sol White, American Baseball HOF executive (Philadelphia Giants 4 x consecutive black C'ships 1904–1907), born in Bellaire, Ohio (d. 1955)

Wallace Sabine, American physicist (father of architectural acoustics), born in Richwood, Ohio (d. 1919) [1]

Karl Landsteiner

Austrian immunologist and pathologist (Nobel 1930 for the discovery of different blood groups), born in Baden bei Wien, Austria-Hungary

Miklós Horthy, Hungarian navy admiral, military leader, anti-communist statesman (Regent of Kingdom of Hungary, 1920-44), and Nazi abettor, born in Kenderes, Austria-Hungary (d. 1957)

Heinrich Schenker, Austrian musicologist (Urlinie) know for his Schenkerian analysis of music, born in Wisniowczyki, Austrian Galicia (now Vyshnivchyk, Ukraine) (d. 1935)

Helen Miller Shepard, American philanthropist who established Hall of Fame, born in Manhattan, New York (d. 1938)

Edwin Stephen Goodrich, English zoologist, born in Weston-super-Mare, Somerset, England (d. 1946)

George Ellery Hale, American astronomer (discovery of magnetic fields in sunspot), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1938)

C. V. France, British actor (The Skin Game, Adventure in Blackmail), born in Bradford, England (d. 1949)

Henrietta Swan Leavitt, American astronomer (period-luminosity relation), born in Lancaster, Massachusetts (d. 1921)

William Henry Singer, American painter and collector (Singer Museum, Laren), born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania (d. 1943)

Princess Victoria of the United Kingdom, fourth child and second daughter of Edward VII and Alexandra of Denmark, born in Marlborough House, London (d. 1935)

Stefan George, German lyric poet (Algabal), born in Büdesheim, Germany (d. 1933)

Gertrude Bell

British archaeologist (Desert & The Sown), born in Washington Hall, County Durham, England

Miron Cristea, 1st Patriarch of All Romania, Prime Minister of Romania (1938-39), born in Toplița, Romania (d. 1939)

George Morren, Flemish painter and sculptor, born in Antwerp (d. 1941)

Jul 28 Thomas P. Krag, Norwegian author and novelist (Jon Graeff, Ulf Ran), born in Kragerø, Norway (d. 1913)

Alfred Weber, German economist and sociologist, born in Erfurt, Prussian Saxony (d. 1958)

Constantine I

King of Greece (1913-17, 20-22), born in Athens, Greece

Oskar Merikanto [Ala-Kanto], Finnish pianist, organist, and composer, born in Helsinki, Grand Duchy of Finland (d. 1924)

Paul Claudel, French poet and playwright (L'Otage-1909), born in Villeneuve-sur-Fère, France (d. 1955)

Granville Bantock, English composer and conductor (Hebridean Symphony), born in London (d. 1946)

Aug 7 Ladislaus Bortkiewicz, Russian mathematician (Poisson distribution) and economist, born in Saint Petersburg, Imperial Russia (d. 1931)

Hugo Eckener

German inventor and commander of the famous Graf Zeppelin during its record-setting flights, born in Flensburg, Schleswig-Holstein

Paul Warburg, German-American investment banker who influenced and encouraged the design of the Federal Reserve, born in Hamburg, Germany (d. 1932)

Frederic Thesiger, 1st Viscount Chelmsford, 22nd Governor of New South Wales (1908-13) and Viceroy of British India (1916-21), born in London, England (d. 1933)

Leone Sinigaglia, Italian composer, born in Turin, Italy (d. 1944)

Bernarr McFadden, American physical culture advocate, credited with beginning the culture of health and fitness in the United States, born in Mill Spring, Missouri (d. 1955)

Aug 16 Charles Sanford Skilton, American composer (Suite Primeval), born in Northhampton, Massachusetts (d. 1941)

Ellen Roosevelt, American tennis player (US Nat C'ship 1890), born in Rosedale, New York (d. 1954)

Willis Rodney Whitney, American Chemist, founder of the General Electric research laboratory, and pioneer of industrial scientific research, born in Jamestown, NY (d. 1958)

Paul Otlet, Belgian author, lawyer and peace activist (created the Universal Decimal Classification scheme), born in Brussels, Belgium (d. 1944)

Nikolaos Levidis, Greek shooter, born in Corfu Island, Greece (d. 1942)

Henri Bourassa, French Canadian politician and publisher (d. 1952)

Heinrich Häberlin, Swiss politician, member of the Federal Council, born in Weinfelden, Switzerland (d. 1947)

Mary Austin, American nature writer and early feminist (Land of Little Rain), born in Carlinville, Illinois (d. 1934)

Dirk Berend Nanninga, Dutch painter (d. 1954)

James Alexander Calder, Canadian politician, born in Oxford County, Ontario (d. 1956)

Olga Knipper. Russian-Soviet stage actress, and wife of Anton Chekhov, born in Glazov, Russian Empire (d. 1959)

Henry F. Gilbert, American composer (The Dance in Place Congo), and musicologist, born in Somerville, Massachusetts (d. 1928)

Marcelo Torcuato de Alvear, President of Argentina (1922-28), born in Buenos Aires, Argentina (d. 1942)

Fred Hovey

American tennis player (US Nationals 1895), born in Newton Centre, Massachusetts

Max Slevogt, German painter, born in Landshut, Germany (d. 1932)

Guillermo M. Tomás, Cuban composer, born in Cienfuegos, Cuba (d. 1933)

August Horch

German engineer and automobile pioneer who founded Audi, born in Winningen, Germany

Franz Ritter von Epp, German general and Nazi official (Reichsstatthalter for Bavaria 1933-45), born in Munich, Bavaria (d. 1947)

Ernst Didring, Swedish author (d. 1931)

Bertha Knight Landes, American politician (1st female mayor of any major US city - Mayor of Seattle 1926-28), born in Ware, Massachusetts (d. 1943)

Frederick Lanchester, English Engineer who built the first British petrol automobile (1896), born in London, England (d. 1946)

Alexandra David-Néel, Belgian-French explorer and writer, born in Saint-Mandé, France (d. 1969)

Annie Patterson, Irish organist, composer, and musicologist, born in Lurgan, Ireland (d. 1934)

James Connolly, American athlete and author, 1st Modern Olympic Champion in 1896, born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 1957)

Carolina “La Belle” Otero, Spanish actress, singer and courtesan, born in Valga, Galicia, Spain (d. 1965)

Felix Hausdorff, German mathematician (Hausdorff space), born in Breslau, Kingdom of Prussia (d. 1942)

Andrea d'Angeli, Italian composer, born in Padua, Kingdom of Italy (d. 1940)

Nov 9 Emmanuel de Bom, Flemish author (Wrakken), born in Antwerp, Belgium (d. 1953)

Marie Dressler

Canadian-American actress (Dinner at 8, Min and Bill), born in Cobourg, Ontario

Gichin Funakoshi, Japanese martial artist, Father of Japanese Shotokan Karatedo, born in Shuri, Okinawa, Japan (d. 1957)

Édouard Vuillard, French painter and graphic artist, born in Cuiseaux, Saône-et-Loire, France (d. 1940)

Pierre Maurice, Swiss composer, born in Allaman, Switzerland (d. 1936)

Ferruccio Giannini, Italian-American operatic tenor (one of the first to be recorded), teacher, and impresario (Verdi Opera House, Philadelphia), born in Barga, Italy (d. 1948)

John Nance Garner, American Democratic politician and lawyer (32nd Vice President of the U.S.), born in Red River County, Texas (d. 1967)

Scott Joplin

American ragtime entertainer and composer ("Maple Leaf Rag"; "The Entertainer"), born in Texarkana, Texas

František Drdla, Czech composer, born in Žďár nad Sázavou, Czech Republic (d. 1944)

Nov 28 William H. Lewis, American College football center and coach (first African-American selected as an All-American; Harvard), born in Berkley, Virginia (d. 1949)

Francis Jammes, French poet and writer (Jammisme), born in Tournay, Hautes-Pyrénées, France (d. 1938)

Jesse Burkett, American Baseball HOF left fielder (NL batting champion 1895-96, 1901; 240 hits in 1896 MLB record for 15 years; Cleveland Spiders, St. Louis Perfectos/Cardinals), born in Wheeling, West Virginia (d. 1953)

Dec 4 Richard Nicolaas Roland Holst, Dutch artist and painter, born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1938)

Arnold Sommerfeld, German physicist, born in Königsberg, Prussia (d. 1951)

Fritz Haber, German physicist and chemist (Nobel 1918 for process to synthesize ammonia), born in Breslau, Prussia (d. 1934)

Louis Victor Saar, Dutch-American composer, born in Rotterdam (d. 1937)

Ernst Henrik Ellberg, Swedish composer, born in Söderhamn, Sweden (d. 1948)

Richard Batka, Austrian music critic and composer, born in Prague, Kingdom of Bohemia (now Czech Republic) (d. 1922)

Harvey S. Firestone

American industrialist and founder of Firestone Tire and Rubber Company ("where the rubber meets the road"), born in Columbiana, Ohio

Emanuel Lasker, German World Chess Champion (1894-21), born in Barlinek, Poland (d. 1941)

Eugenie Besserer, American actress (Jazz Singer), born in Watertown, New York (d. 1934)

Marie van Regteren Altena, Dutch painter (Amsterdam's Joffers), born in Amsterdam, Netherlands (d. 1958)
